title: A car is running at a speed of 60 km per hour. How much will it take to cover the distance of 300 km? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not mentioned whether given speed is constant or average. for the sake of answering lets consider it as constant mathematically speaking it will cover 60 km every hour, taking a total of 5 hours. Practically speaking this time can increase for e.g. usually there is a speedo error , if it shows 60 then actually the car could be running at 55 kmph which means its covered 275 km at the end of 5 hours and additonal 25 -30 mins to complete 300 km. The car / Driver might need a cooling/bio break/ fuel filling of about 15–20 min in between. the car could require infinite time in case it is running on something like a dynamometer where the car wheels are rotating but car is steady at one place.

How much what? Petrol? Concentration? Tyre wear? These homework questions are so poorly written these days. Whatever it is, the car or driver won’t have consumed it all yet, as the car is still running, as indicated by the use of the present continuous case in the first sentence.
The car covers a distance of 60km in 1 hour. So, it will cover a distance of 300 km in= 300/60×1 = 5×1= 5 hours. Hence, the answer is 5 hours.

How much, eh? Let’s say the car uses fuel 55 miles to the gallon. 300/55 = 5.4545 which we will call 5.5 The price of petrol is 1.56 USD per gallon. 5.5 x 1.56 = 8.58 So the trip costs 8.58. By the way if you asked for how much time it takes, it takes 5 hours.
Speed = distance / time V = d / t 60 =300 / t 60 . t = 300 t = 300 / 6 t = 5 hours
Answer is trivial that is five hours; but technically it may not be correct, unless any vehicle moves with uniform speed. Nothing in the universe moves with with uniform motion except earth.
